newsitem.title: USA: Latin American debts mixed, Russia sells off.
newsitem.headline: Latin American debts mixed, Russia sells off.

text.p: Latin American debt prices meandered in directionless trading, while Russia took a pounding by rumors of Minfin bond default, traders said.
A raft of economic data from Latin American countries confirmed the existing trends, without providing new impetus for trading, they said.
Argentine papers got a brief lift by the 7.0 percent rise in July industrial production, but failed to hold on to the gains.
"The figure was actually higher than expected, showing the recovery on track," said Richard Segal, head of emerging market fixed income research at Santander Investments.
Sentiments on Argentina turned cautious in the past month as investors watched how the new economy minister Roque Fernadez would tackle the fiscal deficits.
The International Monetary Fund officials in Buenos Aires this week are likely to agree to a "negotiated waiver" on the deficit target, Segal said.
Argentina FRBs and Pars each shed 3/8 to 76-7/8 and 54-1/2.
Brazil industrial production in June rose 0.5 percent from May, but fell 3.9 percent compared to a year ago.
"Obviously Brazil was not doing as well as Argentina in the second quarter," said a U.S. bank trader.
Brazil papers were lightly mixed, with Brazil C sliding 1/4 to 64-7/8 while Brazil discount Z adding 1/8 to 71-5/8.
Mexico reported preliminary trade surplus totaled $461, with sharp increases in both exports and imports.
"The figure is as good as it can be," Santander's Segal said, noting, however, with the peso stubbornly strong, the future of building trade surpluses was not reassuring.
Rumors, later denied, that another tranche of the Minfin bond is frozen triggered the selloff in Russia before the U.S. trading began.
Positive developments that the IMF agreed to release $330 million, part of a $10.2 billion three-year loan approved in February and a ceasefire with Chechen rebels failed to help trim losses.
"It's the first major seloff," said the U.S. bank trader. "but it remains to be seen if the sentiments have changed."
Russia dollar Vnesh fell 1-1/4 59-5/8 and Min Fin 4 lost 1-1/2 to 47-7/8.
